subject: MORE OF THE SAME
verse: "Is the same yesterday and today and forever." (Heb. 13:8)
reflection: What is in store for the New Year? More of the same-that's what life seems like to many of us. Though some may have new experiences and excitement this nnew year-life for many of us will be one day strung behind the nother with the same tasks hovering before our eyes and the same troubles settling on our shoulders. It doesn't make much difference what number we write for the year. Thank God one thing never changes. Would we want a Lord who changes His mind and issues a recall for promises He made yesterday? A Lord who forgets His full payment for all our sins and now demands that we cover sin's debt? A Lord who closes the door to heaven He once opened with His resurrection? More of the same! YES that's what we need and that's what we have in the Savior Jesus Christ, who "Is the same yesterday and today and forever." Heb. 13:8
prayer: My prayer is that you will have a Happy and Safe New Year.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: For the Lord protects the bones of the righteous; not one of them is broken! 21 Calamity will surely overtake the wicked, and those who hate the righteous will be punished. 22 But the Lord will redeem those who serve him. No one who takes refuge in him will be condemned.
reflection: This was a prophecy about Christ when He was crucified. Even though it was the Roman custom to break the legs of the victim to speed dead, not one of Jesus' bones were broken. The Psalmist says, "Those who hate the righteous will be punished. " What is meant here is those who have cause pain to the Christian will one day find themselves, forsaken, wretched and alone. As we should be aware "The Lord Has redeemed those who serve Him. " The ransom was paid by Christ on the cross. What a tremendous promise we have here as chapter 34 comes to an end.
prayer: O Lord so often we hear that Christians are being tormented and tortured around the world, I thank You for the promise that one day the unrighteous will pay for their crimes. As we have come to the close of another year I pray that Your Spirit would bless each person who reads these devotions. I pray this in the name of Jesus. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: They repay me evil for good. I am sick with despair Yet when they were ill, I grieved for them. I denied myself by fasting for them, but my prayers returned unanswered.
reflection: In the previous verses of this chapter David prayed for God's intervention but he was sad because he thought his prayers were going unanswered. When our prayers are delayed, it is easy to assume that God has not answered, but remember God hears our every prayer which He answers according to His wisdom. Don't let the absence of an immediate answer cause you to doubt or resent God. Instead, let it be an occasion to deepen your faith.
prayer: O Lord, I pray that you would deepen my faith in You so that when You choose to delay the answers to my prayers I would not become doubtful, but remember that You are faithful knowing what is best for me. . . Amen

subject: THOUGHT
verse: The wicked arrogantly hunt down the poor. Let them be caught in the evil they plan for others. 3 For they brag about their evil desires; they praise the greedy and curse the Lord. 4 The wicked are too proud to seek God. They seem to think that God is dead.
reflection: Some people succeed in everything they do, and they brag that no one not even God, can keep them down. We may wonder why God allows these people to gain great wealth while they despise Him as they do. Bur why are we upset when the wicked prosper? Are we angry about the damage they are doing or just jealous of their success? To answer these questions we must gain the right perspective on wickedness and wealth. The wicked will surely be punished because God hates their evil deeds. We need to remember wealth is only temporary. It is not necessarily a sign of God's approval. Don't let wealth become your obsession.
prayer: Dear Lord, I beg two favors of You before I die. First, help me to never tell a lie. Second, give me neither poverty nor riches! Give me just enough to satisfy my needs. . . Amen.

prayer: Dear Lord we would not think of depriving our bodies of food and water when they hunger and thirst. So I pray that I would always seek the nourishing spiritual food that comes to us through Your Word. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: Take delight in the Lord, and He will give you your heart's desires. 5 Commit everything you do to the Lord. Trust Him, and He will help you.
reflection: David calls us to "take delight in the Lord, and commit everything we have and do to Him. " But how do we do this? To delight in someone means to experience great pleasure and joy in his or her presence. This, can only happen when we know this person well. So to delight in the Lord, we must know Him better. Knowledge of God's great love for us will indeed give us delight. "To commit ourselves to the Lord, " means entrusting everything-our lives, families, jobs, possessions-to His control and guidance. To commit ourselves to the Lord means to trust in Him, believing that He can care for us better than we can care for ourselves. We should be willing to wait patiently for Him to work out what is best for us. . .
prayer: O Lord, Help me to remain faithful to a steady diet of Your Word so that I will get to know You as I should. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: Once I was young, and now I am old. Yet I have never seen the godly abandoned or their children begging for bread. 26 The godly always give generous loans to others, and their children are a blessing. 27 Turn from evil and do good, and you will live in the land forever.
reflection: Because there are starving children today, as there were in David's day-what did David mean by these words? "The children of the righteous need not go hungry because other believers should help them in their time of need. " In David's day, Israel obeyed God's laws, which ensured that the poor were treated fairly and mercifully. As long as Israel was obedient, there was enough food for everyone. When Israel forgot God, the rich took care of themselves only, and the poor suffered. When we see a Christian brother or sister suffering today, we can respond in one of three ways. (1) We can say, as Job's friends did-that the afflicted person brought this on himself. (2) We can say, this is a test to help the person develop more patience and trust in God. (3) We can help the person in need. David would approve of only the last option. Although many governments today have their own programs for helping those in needthis is no excuse for ignoring the poor and needy within our reach. . .
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus, , by the gift of Your Holy Spirit, make possible in me a loving heart So that I would reach out to the poor and needy-that I may keep your commandments, abiding in Your love. I give thee thanks. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: 1 O Lord, don't rebuke me in your anger or discipline me in your rage!
reflection: As a child may cry to his father, so David cried to God. David was not saying, "Don't punish me, " but "Don't punish me while You are angry. " What I see here is that he was acknowledging that he did deserved to be punished, but he asked that God would temper His discipline with mercy. Like children, we are free to ask for mercy, but we should not deny that we deserve punishment.
prayer: Dear Lord, like David, I pray that You would temper my discipline with mercy, I have sinned and deserve to be disciplined but do it in mercy I pray in Jesus name. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: Your arrows have struck deep, and your blows are crushing me 3 Because of your anger, my whole body is sick; my health is broken because of my sins 4 My guilt overwhelms me- it is a burden too heavy to bear. (Ps. 38:2-4)
reflection: David saw his anguish as judgment for his sins-although God does not always send physical illness to punish us for our sins-this verse and others in Scripture indicate that He does in certain circumstances. Our sin can have physical or mental side effects that can cause a great amount of suffering. Sometimes God has to punish His children in order to bring them back to Himself. When we repent of our sins God promises to forgive us. He will deliver us from sins eternal consequences-but He does not promise to deliver us from all of sin's earthly consequences.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: My enemies lay traps to kill me. Those who wish me harm make plans to ruin me. All day long they plan their treachery. 13 But I am deaf to all their threats. I am silent before them as one who cannot speak. 14 I choose to hear nothing, and I make no reply.
reflection: It is extremely difficult to remain silent when others tear us down, because we want to protect our reputation. We find it difficult to do nothing while they attack something so precious to us. But we do not have to lash out in revenge or justify our position, we can trust God to protect our reputation. Jesus was silent before His accusers (Lk. 23:9, 10). He left His case in the God's hands (I Pet. 2:21-24). That is a good place to leave our case too!
prayer: O Lord, I thank You, that You are a forgiving God, and that I can come confessing my sins with full confidence that You will forgive them all. And so I lay them at Your feet knowing I have been forgiven. . . Amen.

reflection: Sorrow for our sins can result in a changed behavior. The trouble is many people are sorry only for the results of their sins or for being caught ("sorrow without repentance"). prayer: I Thank You, Lord, that when we bring our sins to You in true repentancewe will be restored-What a wonderful assurance of Your grace and mercy. . . Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: 19 I have many aggressive enemies; they hate me without reason. 0 They repay me evil for good and oppose me for pursuing good. 21 Do not abandon me, O Lord. Do not stand at a distance, my God. 22 Come quickly to help me, O Lord my savior.
reflection: People who are morally upright expose and shame those who aren't. If we live for God the world will often hate us, because we make them painfully aware of their immoral way of living. We see a bit of fear in David which is not too difficult to understand, because his enemies were out to get him. Fear can turn into a dark shadow that will eventually envelope us and ultimately imprison us within ourselves. But we can conquer fear by using the bright liberating light of the Lord who brings salvation. If we want to dispel the darkness of fear, let us remember with the psalmist that "the Lord is my light and salvation. " (Ps. 27:1)
prayer: O Lord, forgive me, for complaining to anyone who will listen, while I often praise You in private-Help me remember to complain in private and praise You publicly. I pray this in Jesus name, Amen.

subject: THOUGHT
verse: I said to myself, "I will watch what I do and not sin in what I say. I will hold my tongue when the ungodly are around me. " 2 But as I stood there in silence- not even speaking of good thingsthe turmoil within me grew worse. 3 The more I thought about it, the hotter I got, igniting a fire of words:
reflection: David resolved to keep his tongue from sin, that is, he decided not to complain to other people about God's treatment of him. All though David did have a reason to complain. David was the anointed king of Israel, but he had to wait many years before taking the throne. Then one of his sons tried to kill him and become king instead. When David could not keep still any longer, he took his complaints directly to God. We may all have complaints about our job, or money, or situation, but complaining to others may make them think that God cannot take care of us. It may also look as if we blame God for our troubles. Instead, like David, we should take our complaints directly to God.
prayer: O Lord, I ask that You would forgive me for complaining about the little things of life when there are so many things I should really be thanking You for, like my health, home, family, friends, the freedom of worship-the freedom of speech-the list could go on and on. For these things I do truly thank You. . . Amen.
